thread.title: Prep volleyball roundup: Cards clip the Knights
thread.title_full: Prep volleyball roundup: Cards clip the Knights

author: Lorrie Reyes
title: Prep volleyball roundup: Cards clip the Knights
text:
Prep volleyball roundup: Cards clip the Knights SCCS gets best of rivals; Hart, Valencia ready for showdown Posted: October 13, 2015 10:03   13, 2015 10:03 p.m. 
The biggest volleyball match on Tuesday night might not have been a Foothill League contest. 
It might have, instead, been Santa Clarita Christian taking on crosstown, conference rival Trinity Classical Academy. 
The Cardinals, who are the No. 1 ranked girls volleyball team in the CIF-Southern Section 5AA Division, came into the matchup with a perfect 3-0 Heritage League record. 
The No. 6 ranked Knights carried a 1-0 Heritage mark. 
Someone had to pick up a conference game. 
Ultimately, SCCS was able to hold off Trinity at Legacy Volleyball Club in a 3-1 win by scores of 25-15, 25-22, 24-26, 25-21. 
“We played solid volleyball,” said SCCS head coach Darcy Brown. “It was a good battle between the two schools.” 
SCCS was led by Kylie Brown, who had a game-high 20 kills, along with 14 digs, three aces and one block. 
Jessica McCarty added five kills, three aces and a block for the Cardinals, while Vanessa Cardenas had six aces, three kills and 14 assists. 
The Cardinals (10-1 overall) took the first two games, but the Knights (18-8-1) were determined not to be swept and came back to win game three, 26-24. 
“It definitely was a battle, and we were proud of the kids for coming back and winning game 3,” said Trinity head coach Alison Buchanan. “We feel like we had too many unforced errors. We didn’t necessarily feel like we got beat by a better team. They played better than we did today, but it was frustrating having us back up their points. 
“We look forward to playing them again.” 
The Knights were led by JaNasjia Bethke who hit the double digit figures in both aces and kills (with 10 each). Emily Buchanan had eight kills and five blocks, while Taylor Oshiro added six kills and another five blocks. 
Valencia 3, Canyon 0 
The Vikings continue to cruise through the Foothill League as they swept the Cowboys 3-0 by scores of 25-10, 25-22, 25-10 at Valencia High Tuesday. 
Lauren Russ, who was sidelined for the first two league matches due to a rolled ankle and returned last Thursday for Valencia, had a game-high 13 kills for the Vikings. 
Valencia’s Holly Pittman, Emily Burns, and Bri Coleman each tallied six kills in the win. This was Coleman’s first league match after she sat out the required 30-day period for transferring from Saugus. 
Canyon’s Sasha Oakley led the Cowboys with nine kills, while Breanna Kelley added six kills on the night. Freshman libero CJ Catabona had 12 digs in the loss. 
The Cowboys are still searching for a Foothill win as they move to 0-4 in league and 5-6 overall. 
Valencia has only dropped one game in its four matches so far in conference play and remain unbeaten in both league play (4-0) and overall (8-0). 
Hart 3, Golden Valley 0 
Hart also kept the pedal to the metal, as it swept its match against Golden Valley by scores of 25-11, 25-9, 25-9. 
Amy McKee and Brooke Boron led the Indians on the attack with seven and six kills, respectively. 
McKee also had a nice service night with three aces, but it was Sarah Coblentz that led Hart with seven aces. 
Outside hitter Kelsey Bauer had seven kills for the Grizzlies. 
“They jumped on us every game, and they played really well,” said Golden Valley Erick Beck about Hart. “They looked like they were playing for a league title.” 
Although it wasn’t playing for a league title at Hart High on Tuesday, the Indians do face off with the Vikings on Thursday at Valencia High. 
Hart improves to 4-0 in the Foothill play and 8-3 overall. Golden Valley moves to 6-10 overall and 1-3 in league with the loss. 
West Ranch 3, Saugus 1 
West Ranch picked up its second straight league win, defeating Saugus 3-1 by scores of 25-14, 25-17, 19-25, 25-20. 
Annika Bergstrom and Tasha Skabelund both had 10 kills for the Wildcats. Kaitlin Schultz had three blocks, while Katie Jacobs had 35 assists, and Ryann Desser had 14 digs. 
Caitlin Liebe and Alison Ritchie each had six kills for the Centurions, who drop to 1-3 in the Foothill League and 9-11 overall. 
“It was a rough night,” said Saugus head coach Eric Luckenbach. “This was the most disconnected that we’ve been. But a lot of the things that we are doing are in our control.” 
Luckenbach said the Cents have struggled with health in the beginning of the season, but Tuesday night they were able to finally have everyone back on the court. 
Saugus will try to rebound when it travels to Canyon tomorrow. For West Ranch (10-7, 2-2), it hopes it can stay on its winning streak as it battles Golden Valley on Thursday.
